documents.title: Common Drug Classes and Mechanisms
documents.content:
Comprehensive overview of major drug classes used in clinical practice.

Cardiovascular:
- Beta-blockers (-olol): Block β1/β2 receptors, reduce HR, contractility, BP
- ACE inhibitors (-pril): Block angiotensin-converting enzyme, reduce angiotensin II
- ARBs (-sartan): Block angiotensin II receptors, similar effects to ACEi
- CCBs: Dihydropyridine (amlodipine) - vasodilation; Non-DHP (diltiazem, verapamil) - rate control
- Statins (-statin): HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, lower LDL cholesterol
- Diuretics: Thiazides (HCTZ), Loops (furosemide), K-sparing (spironolactone)

Anticoagulants:
- Heparin/LMWH: Activate antithrombin III
- Warfarin: Vitamin K antagonist, inhibits II, VII, IX, X
- DOACs: Direct thrombin or Factor Xa inhibitors

Antimicrobials:
- Beta-lactams: Inhibit cell wall synthesis (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems)
- Fluoroquinolones: Inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
- Macrolides: Inhibit 50S ribosome, protein synthesis
- Aminoglycosides: Inhibit 30S ribosome, bactericidal
- Vancomycin: Cell wall synthesis inhibition, gram-positive coverage

Analgesics:
- NSAIDs: COX-1/2 inhibition, anti-inflammatory, antipyretic, analgesic
- Opioids: Mu receptor agonists, central analgesia
- Acetaminophen: Central mechanism, antipyretic/analgesic without anti-inflammatory

Antidiabetics:
- Metformin: Decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis, first-line T2DM
- Sulfonylureas: Stimulate insulin secretion
- SGLT2 inhibitors (-gliflozin): Increase urinary glucose excretion
- GLP-1 agonists (-tide): Incretin mimetics, weight loss benefit
